23 ■ INTRODUCTION 24 The remarkable optoelectronic properties and high surface 25 areas of layered two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials have 26 sparked widespread research interest.1 Most notably, the 27 transition-metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) are intensively 28 investigated as next-generation semiconductors with applica29 tions in the fields of optoelectronics, catalysis, sensing, or 30 energy storage.2−6 Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) is by far the 31 most studied member of the TMD family. As a bulk crystal, 32 MoS2 adopts a layered crystal structure consisting of stacked 33 S−Mo−S monolayers. The relatively weak dispersion forces 34 between the layers favor the production of ultrathin mono- and 35 few-layered TMDs using different methods.4 Currently, 36 vacuum deposition and mechanical exfoliation are the most 37 commonly used techniques to manufacture high-quality 38 TMDs,7 yet their high synthesis cost and limited scalability 39 remain key issues. These drawbacks have raised interest in 40 more scalable production methods. As a result, solution-based 41 methods, such as top-down liquid-phase exfoliation (LPE) and 42 bottom-up colloidal synthesis, have attracted significant 43 research interest. These methods are scalable, and solution44 based processing through a variety of deposition methods, e.g., 45 dip- and spin-coating, offers an exciting road to device 46 integration.
47Both LPE and colloidal synthesis rely on a tight interplay 48between the inorganic and the organic interface. On the one 49hand, seminal studies on layered 2D materials systematically 50demonstrated that stable dispersions of exfoliated nanomateri51als are only obtained in solvents with well-defined solubility 52parameters δs at around 20−27 MPa1/2.8−12 These results have 53been rationalized within a broader context of solution 54thermodynamics where a matching of the solubility parameter 55of the solvent and the nanomaterial minimizes the energy of 56mixing. Knowledge of solubility parameters proved essential to 57determine suitable conditions for high-yield exfoliations and 58offered the prospect of postprocessing where stable solvent59exfoliated dispersions were processed into printable inks to 60fabricate printed devices, such as thin-film transistors.13 A 61colloidal synthesis, on the other hand, produces dispersions of 62hybrid nanocrystals where both the inorganic core and the 63organic surfactant shell contribute to the properties of the

The ligand shell has a pivotal role in the 67 stabilization of NC dispersion17 but also controls the shape18 68 and the size19 of the nanocrystal during growth. In a similar 69 way as it did for LPE nanomaterials, rational control of the 70 interface proved indispensable to advance in research areas as 71 diverse as optoelectronics,20,21 catalysis,22 and thermoelec72 trics.23
73 Clearly, in both fields, insights in the inorganic/organic 74 interface layer proved essential to improving the material’s 75 performance. Nevertheless, despite the staggering growth in 76 colloidal transition-metal chalcogenide (c-TMD) synthesis 77 protocols,24−26,26−41 the interface between the NC and the 78 surrounding organic medium is barely understood. Perhaps 79 most remarkably, nearly all proof-of-concept applications 80 involving colloidal TMDs exploit the surface of these 81 compounds either as a catalyst for hydrogen evolution 82 reactions,34,35,38,40,42 as gas sensor,38 as hydrogenation 83 catalyst,33 or as battery materials.32,41 84 In this study, we investigated the inorganic/organic interface 85 of colloidal molybdenum disulfide (c-MoS2) nanosheets made 86 through hot injection. Starting from the observation that the 87 colloidal stability of c-MoS2 heavily depends on the solvent 88 choice, we screened the stability of the synthesized c-MoS2 89 nanosheets in a wide range of solvents. Similar to van der 90 Waals solids produced by LPE, we show that colloidal stability 91 can be understood from solution thermodynamics, where the 92 solubility parameter of the solvent is an apt descriptor to 93 predict the colloidal stability of c-MoS2 nanosheets. More 94 specifically, we found that the most optimal solvents are 95 characterized by a solubility parameter of 21.5 ± 0.3 MPa1/2. 96 Such values are attained by aromatic solvents with polar 97 groups, such as o-dichlorobenzene, or even polar aprotic 98 solvents, such as DMF. These findings are complemented by 99 NMR analyses, which demonstrated ligands, such as oleyl100 amine and oleic acid, have a minimal affinity toward the NC 101 surface and engage in a highly dynamic adsorption/desorption 102 equilibrium. A direct consequence of such a dynamic 103 interaction is that c-MoS2 has limited colloidal stability in 104 typical apolar solvents with a too-low solubility parameter. We 105 thus conclude that hot injection yields c-MoS2 nanosheets with 106 comparable interfaces as those produced by LPE, where 107 colloidal stability of dispersions and inks is linked to a 108 matching of the solvent and nanomaterial solubility parame109 ters. This finding might offer the prospect of using established 110 procedures developed for LPE nanomaterials for postprocess111 ing of colloidally synthesized TMD dispersions as processable 112 inks.

While purifying the dispersions 313presented in Figure 1, we observed rapid aggregation in 314commonly used solvents in nanocrystal syntheses, such as 315(cyclo)hexane, toluene, and chloroform. A similar observation 316had already been reported by Mahler et al.24 In their study, 2H 317WS2 nanosheets tended to aggregate over time, and additional 318washing steps by precipitation rendered the product less 319dispersible in hexane. At the same time we noticed that 320redispersion of c-MoS2 in o-dichlorobenzene resulted in stable 321dispersions that show little or no sedimentation over time. In 322addition, after a routine purification cycle involving the 323removal of the native reaction mixture by centrifugation and 324two additional washing steps with ethanol, we were able to 325redisperse the MoS2 pellet in polar solvents under mild 326sonication. For instance, c-MoS2 dispersed in N,N-dimethyl327formamide, a common exfoliation solvent (vide supra), formed 328colloids that remained stable for months. These observations 329contrast with the behavior of nanocrystals synthesized in an 330apolar reaction mixture by hot injection. For instance, 2D 331CdSe nanoplatelets packed with organic surfactant molecules 332are most stable in (cyclo)hexane,55,56 while QDs are usually 333dispersed in hexane or toluene.57 Additionally, a nanocrystal 334transfer from an apolar to a polar solvent typically involves the 335laborsome exchange of the native apolar surfactant layer to a 336polar ligand shell using a two-phase system.58
337Conceivably, these observations point to a similar 338stabilization mechanism as seen in liquid-phase exfoliated 339layered colloids. Here, conditions for high-yield exfoliations are 340interpretated as a matching of the solubility parameter of the 341solvent and the van der Waals (vdW) solid according to the 342Hildebrand−Scatchard solution theory of mixing.59−61 For a 343bare MoS2 nanosheet, Cunningham et al.
8 estimated the 344solubility parameter to be ≈22 MPa1/2 by screening LPE in a 345wide range of solvents. Interestingly, o-dichlorobenzene has a 346closely matching solubility parameter (20.5 MPa1/2) to the one 347of a bare MoS2 surface. On the other hand, typical apolar 348solvent solubility parameters range from 15 to 18 MPa1/2 and 349match those of usual apolar surfactant molecules used in hot350injection syntheses.62 In this respect, the question stands out as 351to whether the concepts developed for liquid-phase exfoliation 352also apply to nanomaterials synthesized through hot injection. 353Solubility Parameter Matching in Practice. 712 ■ CONCLUSION 713 Reasoning from the observation that the colloidal stability of c714 MoS2 is heavily dependent on the solvent choice, we screened 715 the stability of colloidal MoS2 nanosheets in a wide range of 716 solvents. Similar to van der Waals solids produced by LPE, we 717 show that colloidal stability can be understood from solution 718 thermodynamics, where the solubility parameter of the solvent 719 is an apt descriptor to predict the colloidal stability of c-MoS2 720 nanosheets. More specifically, we found that the most optimal 721 solvents are characterized by a solubility parameter of 21.5 ± 722 0.3 MPa1/2. Such values are attained by aromatic solvents with 723 polar groups, such as o-dichlorobenzene, or even polar aprotic 724 solvents, such as DMF. These findings are complemented by 725 NMR analyses, which demonstrated that ligands, such as 726 oleylamine and oleic acid, have a minimal affinity toward the 727 NC surface and engage in a highly dynamic adsorption/ 728 desorption equilibrium. We thus conclude that hot injection 729 yields c-MoS2 nanosheets with comparable interfaces as those 730 produced by LPE, where colloidal stability of dispersions and 731 inks is linked to a matching of the solvent and nanomaterial 732 solubility parameters. This finding might offer the prospect of 733 using established procedures developed for LPE nanomaterials 734 for postprocessing of colloidally synthesized TMD dispersions 735 as processable inks.
